title: Contributing to meetupr
text: make substantial pull request, always file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s problem. ’ve found bug, create associated issue illustrate bug minimal reprex.

title: Contributing to meetupr
text: recommend create Git branch pull request (PR). Look Travis build status making changes. README contain badges continuous integration services used package. New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat. Contributions test cases included easier accept. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md current development version header describing changes made followed GitHub username, links relevant issue(s)/PR(s).

title: Custom Meetup Queries
text: complete control, build queries using meetup_template_query() directly: example, fetch detailed group info including member count. also demonstrates using variable $urlname flexibility. case, can pass variable calling meetup_query(), allows reusing query different groups. meetup_query() function handles variable substitution passing additional arguments (captured ...). learn explore schema build queries, see API Introspection vignette.
code:
custom_query <- "   query GetGroupWithDetails($urlname: String!) {     groupByUrlname(urlname: $urlname) {       id       name       description       city       country       timezone              memberships {         totalCount       }     }   }" lagos <- meetup_query(   custom_query,   urlname = "rladies-lagos" ) #> Warning in default_backend_auto(): Selecting 'env' backend. Secrets are stored #> in environment variables #> Warning in default_backend_auto(): Selecting 'env' backend. Secrets are stored #> in environment variables lagos #> $data #> $data$groupByUrlname #> $data$groupByUrlname$id #> [1] "32612004" #>  #> $data$groupByUrlname$name #> [1] "R-Ladies Lagos" #>  #> $data$groupByUrlname$description #> [1] "R-Ladies is a world-wide organization to promote gender diversity in the R community.
R-Ladies welcomes members of all R proficiency levels, whether you're a new or aspiring R user, or an experienced R programmer interested in mentoring, networking & expert upskilling. Our community is designed to develop our members' R skills & knowledge through social, collaborative learning & sharing. Supporting minority identity access to STEM skills & careers, the Free Software Movement, and contributing to the global R community!
This is a local chapter of R-Ladies Global, an organisation that promotes gender diversity in the R community worldwide. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R. As a founding principle, there is no cost or charge to participate in any of our R-Ladies communities around the world.
We are part of Global R-Ladies group. You can access our presentations, R scripts, and Projects on our Github account and follow us on twitter to stay up to date about R-Ladies news!
Website: [https://www.rladies.org](https://www.rladies.org)
Twitter: @RLadiesGlobal ( [https://twitter.com/RLadiesGlobal](https://twitter.com/RLadiesGlobal) )
Github: [https://github.com/rladies](https://github.com/rladies)
P.S. Community Policies & Code of Conduct:
The leadership, mentoring & teaching roles within this Community are held exclusively by minority genders (majority gender speakers may be allowed/invited as one-off guests in exceptional circumstances at the leadership team's discretion). Due to unexpected demand, we have opened learning participation to all genders, dependent on initial and on-going vetting by the leadership team. However, the stated priority of the R-Ladies communities is the development & support specifically of those identifying as a minority gender, and we, therefore, reserve the right to guard this interest through whatever measures the leadership team deems appropriate. Anyone involved with R-Ladies is expected to fully respect each other, the mandate of this community, and the goodwill on which R-Ladies is founded, or face expulsion/a penalty of any form, at the discretion of the leadership team.
Full community guidelines are found here: [https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki](https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki)
P.P.S. Photos, Films and all other media/recordings:
Photos, Films, and all other media/recordings: photographs and/or video/other media will be taken at events held by this community. By taking part in an R-Ladies event you grant the community organizers full rights to use the images resulting from the photography/video filming/media, and any reproductions or adaptations of the images for publicity, fundraising or other purposes to help achieve the community’s aims. This might include (but is not limited to), the right to use them in their printed and online publicity, social media, press releases and funding applications. If you do not wish to be recorded in these media please inform a community organizer." #>  #> $data$groupByUrlname$city #> [1] "Lagos" #>  #> $data$groupByUrlname$country #> [1] "ng" #>  #> $data$groupByUrlname$timezone #> [1] "Africa/Lagos" #>  #> $data$groupByUrlname$memberships #> $data$groupByUrlname$memberships$totalCount #> [1] 873  ottawa <- meetup_query(   custom_query,   urlname = "rladies-ottawa" ) #> Warning in default_backend_auto(): Selecting 'env' backend. title: Custom Meetup Queries

title: Custom Meetup Queries
text: request fields need minimize response size:
code: # Don't fetch everything heavy_query <- ' query {   groupByUrlname(urlname: "rladies-sf") {     pastEvents(input: {first: 100}) {       edges {         node {           # All fields including large nested objects         }       }     }   } }'  # Be selective optimized_query <- ' query {   groupByUrlname(urlname: "rladies-sf") {     pastEvents(input: {first: 100}) {       edges {         node {           id           title           dateTime           going           # Only what you need         }       }     }   } }'

title: Meetup API Schema Introspection
text: Use introspection data construct targeted queries meetup_query(): example, fetch event details including title, description, date/time, venue info, associated group details. sets variable $eventId flexibility, can passed calling meetup_query(), allowing reuse different events.
code:
custom_query <- " query($eventId: ID!) {   event(id: $eventId) {     title     description     dateTime     venues {       name       address     }     group {       name       urlname     }   } }" result <- meetup_query(custom_query, eventId = "103349942") #> Warning in default_backend_auto(): Selecting 'env' backend. Secrets are stored #> in environment variables #> Warning in default_backend_auto(): Selecting 'env' backend. Secrets are stored #> in environment variables result #> $data #> $data$event #> $data$event$title #> [1] "Ecosystem GIS & Community Building" #>  #> $data$event$description #> [1] "Hello New DVDC Members!

Is Data Visualization a science or an art? Our goal is to create great events where everyones' experiences reflect that sentiment, and we are beginning a great speaker in Joseph Sexton (http://www.terpconnect.umd.edu/~jsexton/). Joe will give us a glimpse of his department's unique global ecological datasets, with stunning visuals, and what goes into unparalleled GIS data. Joe's datasets include DISCO (Dynamic Impervious Surface Cover Observations) and global 30-m resolution continuous fields of tree cover from 2000 - 2005. Elizabeth Lyon will show us the next evolution of Wikipedia with interactive map visualization by MapStory.

We are excited to have NClud host the event, they have a great aesthetic downtown space that facilitates networking as well as presentations, and as with all Data Community DC (http://www.meetup.com/Data-Visualization-DC/events/103349942/www.datacommunitydc.org) events we cap the night with Data Drinks.

Agenda

6:30pm -- Networking and Refreshments 7:00pm -- Introduction & Announcements 7:15pm -- Presentation #1 7:45pm -- Readjust & Announcements 7:55pm -- Presentation #2 8:25pm -- Q&A - Discussion 8:40pm -- Data Drinks Bios

Joseph Sexton (http://www.terpconnect.umd.edu/~jsexton/)

Joe is a research professor at the University of Maryland whose research focuses on ecosystem dynamics and the remote sensing methods required to monitor landscape changes over time. He developes statistical and ecological analyses for the Global Forest Cover Change Project (http://glcf.umiacs.umd.edu/research/portal/gfcc/index.shtml), a joint project of the Global Land Cover Facility (http://www.glcf.umd.edu/index.shtml), NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center (http://www.nasa.gov/centers/goddard/home/index.html), and South Dakota State University (http://globalmonitoring.sdstate.edu/). The project is mining more than thirty years of Landsat images to map changes in Earth's forest cover from 1975 to 2005. Joe also contributes ecological, statistical, and remote sensing expertise to collaborative studies of urban heat islands, threatened and endangered species habitat, tropical deforestation, climate effects on boreal biomes, and urban growth.

Elizabeth Lyon

Liz is a Geographer with the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. She leads innovative research and technology development in social media, social sciences, and geospatial technology. Currently she works on building technical capacity for spatial narrative development. Elizabeth volunteers her time in Washington DC growing the geospatial community. She is currently completing her Ph.D. in Geography at George Mason University. She has a Certificate in Computational Social Science from George Mason University, a Masters of Science in Geography from University of Illinois and a bachelor’s degree in Economics and French from Augustana College." #>  #> $data$event$dateTime #> [1] "2013-02-18T18:30:00-05:00" #>  #> $data$event$venues #> $data$event$venues[[1]] #> $data$event$venues[[1]]$name #> [1] "Browsermedia/NClud" #>  #> $data$event$venues[[1]]$address #> [1] "1203 19th Street" #>  #>  #>  #> $data$event$group #> $data$event$group$name #> [1] "Data Visualization DC" #>  #> $data$event$group$urlname #> [1] "data-visualization-dc"

title: Meetup API Schema Introspection
text: GraphQL, mutations used modify data. less commonly used data retrieval, ’s useful know ’s available. Mutations allow creating, updating, deleting resources, typical use cases involve managing events, RSVPs, group details. Mutations require users appropriate permissions perform actions. Check mutations available: Available mutations might include actions like createEvent, updateEvent, deleteEvent, etc.

title: Meetup API Schema Introspection
text: build mutation query, follow similar process queries. example, create new event, might construct mutation like :
code: mutation_query <- " mutation($input: CreateEventInput!) {   createEvent(input: $input) {     event {       id       title       dateTime     }   } }"  # Example input for creating an event input_data <- list(   title = "New Meetup Event",   description = "Description of the new event",   dateTime = "2024-07-01T18:00:00Z",   groupId = "123456" )  # Execute the mutation (requires appropriate permissions) meetup_query(mutation_query, input = input_data)

title: Setting up and Getting Started with meetupr
text: don’t provide value, prompted input interactively. Using Stored Credentials authentication needed, meetupr package automatically retrieve stored credentials:
code: # Store client ID and secret in keyring meetup_key_set("client_id", "your_client_id") meetup_key_set("client_secret", "your_secret") # Retrieve client ID and secret (used internally by meetupr) client_id <- meetup_key_get("client_id") client_secret <- meetup_key_get("client_secret")

title: R-Ladies chapters on meetup.com
code: library(tidytext) library(ggwordcloud) library(dplyr) library(tidyr) library(ggplot2) library(meetupr)

what: How many R-Ladies chapter are out there?
title: R-Ladies chapters on meetup.com
text: can use find_groups() function search groups “r-ladies” name. Note function returns 200 results, filter afterwards. Since search might return groups actually R-Ladies chapters, filter name. Now, searching R-Ladies chapters nice way get started, reliable way use get_pro_groups() function, retrieves official R-Ladies chapters. Since R-Ladies pro organization meetup.com, can use function get list chapters part R-Ladies network.
code: meetup_groups <- find_groups("r-ladies") meetup_groups rladies <- meetup_groups |>   filter(grepl("R-Ladies", name, ignore.case = TRUE))  rladies rladies_pro <- get_pro_groups("rladies")

title: R-Ladies chapters on meetup.com
text: Let us now visualize growth R-Ladies chapters time.
code: df <- rladies_pro |>   mutate(     dategroup = format(founded_date, "%Y-%m")   ) |>   group_by(dategroup) |>   tally() |>   mutate(     cum_sum = cumsum(n)   )  ggplot(   data = df,   aes(x = dategroup, y = cum_sum) ) +   geom_bar(     stat = "identity",     color = "#88398A",     fill = "#88398A"   ) +   theme_bw() +   labs(     title = "Growth of R-Ladies chapters",     caption = "Data from meetup.com via the meetupR package",     x = "",     y = "Number of chapters"   ) +   theme(     axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, vjust = 1, hjust = 1)   ) +   scale_x_discrete(     breaks = df$dategroup[seq(1, length(df$dategroup), by = 2)]   )

title: R-Ladies chapters on meetup.com
text: Let us now extract number past events dates last next events, chapter. chapters never events even planned one (created 6 months ago)? chapters events past 6 months even planned one?
code: rladies_events <- get_pro_events("rladies")  event_summary <- rladies_events |>   group_by(group_name, group_urlname) |>   summarise(     n_past = ifelse("PAST" %in% status, length(status), 0),     last_event = ifelse(       "PAST" %in% status,       format(max(date_time[status == "PAST"]), "%Y-%m-%d"),       NA     ),     next_event = ifelse(       "ACTIVE" %in% status,       format(min(date_time[status == "ACTIVE"]), "%Y-%m-%d"),       NA     )   ) event_summary rladies <- rladies_pro |>   rename(group_urlname = urlname) |>   left_join(event_summary, by = "group_urlname")  rladies |>   filter(     n_past == 0,     is.na(next_event),     founded_date < Sys.Date() - 6 * 30   ) |>   arrange(founded_date) rladies |>   filter(     last_event < as.POSIXct("2019-03-29"),     is.na(next_event)   ) |>   arrange(last_event)

title: R-Ladies chapters on meetup.com
text: Finally, let us create wordcloud common words event descriptions R-Ladies chapters.
code: # Strip html tags from event descriptions strip_html <- function(x) {   sapply(x, function(x) {     gsub("<[^>]+>", "", x)   }) }  #' custom function to create wordcloud data rladies_wc <- function(data, column, n = 100) {   data |>     unnest_tokens(word, {{ column }}) |>     anti_join(stop_words, by = "word") |>     filter(       !grepl("^[0-9]+$", word),       nchar(word) > 2,       !word %in% c("p", "br", "href", "http", "https", "class", "www", "com"),       !word %in%         c(           "de",           "la",           "et",           "les",           "des",           "le",           "en",           "un",           "une",           "du",           "para",           "con",           "del",           "el",           "se",           "y",           "los",           "es"         )     ) |>     count(word, sort = TRUE) |>     slice_max(n, n = n) |>      ggplot(aes(       label = word,       size = n,       color = n     )) +     geom_text_wordcloud() +     scale_size_area(max_size = 12) +     scale_color_gradient(       low = "#88398A",       high = "#562457"     ) +     theme_minimal() } rladies_wc(rladies_events, description) +   labs(     title = "Most common words in R-Ladies event descriptions",     caption = "Data from meetup.com via the meetupr package"   )

title: Find groups using text-based search — find_groups
text: query Character string search groups max_results Maximum number results return. set NULL, return available results (may take long time). handle_multiples Character. handle multiple matches. One "list" "first", "error". "list", return list-column matches. "first", return first match. extra_graphql graphql object. Extra objects return ... empty. Used parameter expansion

title: Meetup API CI Authentication — meetup_ci

title: Meetup API CI Authentication — meetup_ci
code: meetup_ci_setup(client_name = Sys.getenv("MEETUP_CLIENT_NAME", "meetupr"))  meetup_ci_load(client_name = Sys.getenv("MEETUP_CLIENT_NAME", "meetupr"))

title: Meetup API CI Authentication — meetup_ci
text: client_name string representing name client. default, set "meetupr" retrieved MEETUP_CLIENT_NAME environment variable.

title: Meetup API CI Authentication — meetup_ci
text: meetup_setup_ci(): Returns encoded base64 authentication token invisibly. meetup_load_ci(): Returns TRUE invisibly token successfully loaded.

title: Meetup API CI Authentication — meetup_ci
text: meetup_setup_ci() performs following steps: Checks user authenticated Meetup API Reads existing token file OAuth cache directory Encodes token file contents base64 string Stores credentials keyring service name "meetupr" Provides guidance setting environment variables CI Copies encoded token clipboard (available)

title: Meetup API CI Authentication — meetup_ci
text: meetup_load_ci() requires following stored keyring (typically populated environment variables CI): token: base64-encoded token string (service: "meetupr", username: "token") token_file: name token file (service: "meetupr", username: "token_file") decoded token saved OAuth cache directory : {oauth_cache_path}/{client_name}/{token_file}

title: Meetup API CI Authentication — meetup_ci
text: using environment backend (automatically selected keyring support unavailable, CRAN headless CI systems), credentials stored : meetupr:token - base64-encoded token meetupr:token_file - token filename

title: Meetup API CI Authentication — meetup_ci
text: meetup_ci_setup(): Setup authentication CI environments meetup_ci_load(): Load authentication CI environment

title: Meetup API CI Authentication — meetup_ci
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Setup CI authentication (run locally): meetup_setup_ci()  # In your CI pipeline, load the credentials: meetup_load_ci()  # Custom client name: meetup_setup_ci(client_name = "my_custom_client") meetup_load_ci(client_name = "my_custom_client") } # }

what: Manage API keys in system keyring — meetup_keys
title: Manage API keys in system keyring — meetup_keys
text: Store retrieve keys securely using system keyring. Typically used storing OAuth tokens credentials meetupr package.

title: Manage API keys in system keyring — meetup_keys
code: meetup_key_set(   key,   value,   client_name = Sys.getenv("MEETUP_CLIENT_NAME", "meetupr") )  meetup_key_get(   key,   client_name = Sys.getenv("MEETUP_CLIENT_NAME", "meetupr"),   error = TRUE )  meetup_key_delete(   key,   client_name = Sys.getenv("MEETUP_CLIENT_NAME", "meetupr") )

title: Manage API keys in system keyring — meetup_keys
text: key Character string indicating key name store/retrieve. Default "token". Valid options "client_id", "client_secret", "token", "token_file". value Character string value store. NULL (default), prompts interactive input. client_name string representing name client. default, set "meetupr" retrieved MEETUP_CLIENT_NAME environment variable. error Logical. TRUE (default), raises error key found. FALSE, returns NULL.

title: Manage API keys in system keyring — meetup_keys
text: meetup_key_set(): Returns TRUE invisibly success meetup_key_get(): Returns key value, NULL found error = FALSE

title: Manage API keys in system keyring — meetup_keys
text: meetup_key_set(): Store key system keyring meetup_key_get(): Retrieve key system keyring meetup_key_delete(): Delete key system keyring

title: Manage API keys in system keyring — meetup_keys
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ meetup_key_set("token", "my-access-token") meetup_key_set("client_id")  meetup_key_get("token") meetup_key_get("missing_key", error = FALSE) } # }

title: Execute GraphQL query — meetup_query
text: function executes GraphQL query provided variables. validates variables, constructs request, handles errors returned GraphQL API.

title: Execute GraphQL query — meetup_query
code: meetup_query(graphql, ..., .envir = parent.frame())

title: Execute GraphQL query — meetup_query
text: graphql GraphQL query string ... Variables pass query .envir Environment error handling

title: Execute GraphQL query — meetup_query
text: response GraphQL API list.

title: Execute GraphQL query — meetup_query
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ query <- " query GetUser($id: ID!) {  user(id: $id) {   id  name } }" meetup_query(graphql = query, id = "12345") } # }

what: Create and Configure a Meetup API Request — meetup_req
title: Create and Configure a Meetup API Request — meetup_req
text: function prepares configures HTTP request interacting Meetup API. allows user authenticate via OAuth, specify use caching, set custom client configuration.

title: Create and Configure a Meetup API Request — meetup_req
code: meetup_req(rate_limit = 500/60, cache = TRUE, ...)

title: Create and Configure a Meetup API Request — meetup_req
text: rate_limit numeric value specifying maximum number requests cache logical value indicating whether cache OAuth token disk. Defaults TRUE. ... Additional arguments passed meetup_client() setting OAuth client.

title: Create and Configure a Meetup API Request — meetup_req
text: httr2 request object pre-configured interact Meetup API.

title: Create and Configure a Meetup API Request — meetup_req
text: function constructs HTTP POST request directed Meetup API applies appropriate OAuth headers authentication. function prepared support caching provides flexibility client customization ... parameter. implementation currently commented require activation functionality.

title: Create and Configure a Meetup API Request — meetup_req
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Example 1: Basic request with caching enabled req <- meetup_req(cache = TRUE)  # Example 2: Request with custom client ID and secret req <- meetup_req(   cache = FALSE,   client_id = "your_client_id",   client_secret = "your_client_secret" ) } # }

title: Show meetupr authentication status — meetup_sitrep
text: function checks authentication status Meetup API. provides feedback whether credentials configured correctly, tests API connectivity, shows available authentication methods.

title: Show meetupr authentication status — meetup_sitrep
code: meetup_sitrep()

title: Show meetupr authentication status — meetup_sitrep
text: Invisibly returns list authentication status details.

title: meetupr: Access Meetup Data — meetupr-package
text: Provides programmatic access 'Meetup' GraphQL API (https://www.meetup.com/api/schema/), enabling users retrieve information groups, events, members 'Meetup' (https://www.meetup.com/). Supports authentication via 'OAuth2' includes functions common queries data manipulation tasks.

title: meetupr 0.3.0
text: Updated use new Meetup schema February 2025 Switched using httr2 package making API requests instead httr. Uses s7 classes internal query objects instead lists. meetup_query() - Run custom queries Meetup API. meetup_sitrep() - Get information API connection status. meetup_introspect() - Get information Meetup API query options. added deprecation warnings get_meetup_comments(). Added new vignettes Expanded test suite Uses vcr examples vignettes addition tests

title: meetupr 0.2.0
text: mentions arguments related API keys removed Meetup API longer supports authentication API key.

title: meetupr 0.2.0
text: Added automatic rate limiting based response headers. Added support non-interactive use. Added functions getting pro events groups.

title: meetupr 0.2.0
text: Renamed api_method api_path internal function, .fetch_results(), ’s less confusing.

title: meetupr 0.1.1
text: Added get_event_rsvps() function. Contribution Michael Beigelmacher: https://github.com/rladies/meetupr/pull/19

title: meetupr 0.1.0
text: Added NEWS.md file.

title: meetupr 0.1.0
text: Updated get_events(), get_boards(), get_group_members() output tibble summarised information. raw content previously output functions can found resource column output tibble.

title: meetupr 0.1.0
text: Changed name get_meetup_attendees() get_meetup_comments() get_comments() get_attendees() distinction (get_* functions get something group, specific event group). Also updated output functions lists tibbles. raw content previously output functions can found resource column output tibble. Officially deprecated get_meetup_attendees() get_meetup_comments() functions. Added bunch fields get_events() output. Added ability pass vector statuses event_status addition single string. Added find_groups() function get list groups using text-based search. Added short vignette demonstrate use new find_groups() function. Added ... option .quick_fetch() .fetch_results() (internals.R) use parameter GET request. Removed LazyData = TRUE DESCRIPTION file (needed dataset shipped within package). Added .get_api_key() internal function used inside .fetch_results() now api_key = NULL automatically populate variable MEETUP_KEY environment variable, available. Added printout many results returned query users understand ’s taking function finish executing. Renamed api_params api_method internal function, .fetch_results(), since ’s official name argument represents. Added several new columns get_group_members() result tibble (e.g. bio, city, country, lat, lon, etc) Added References section R docs function includes link official Meetup API documentation endpoint.

title: meetupr 0.0.1
text: Initial release.
